title: New Report Finds Retail Energy Key to an Affordable Clean Energy Transition - PR Newswire
summary: A new report finds that consumers in states with restructured energy markets are better off than states still holding onto the monopoly utility model. States that allow competition are also better positioned to support the transition to clean energy, consumer adoption of electric vehicles, and reduce carbon emissions without relying on ratepayer or taxpayer dollars. The report recommends removing barriers to competition and improving consumer protections to realize market benefits.
green_innovation: TRUE, the article describes retail energy choice in states as a green innovation because it allows consumers to choose from a variety of retail energy products that are designed to meet their energy cost management and non-price preferences, and creates the conditions to lower all energy costs in the state market over time.
business_innovation: TRUE, the article describes retail energy choice in states as a business innovation because it is a new or improved business process for one or more business functions that differs significantly from the firm’s previous business processes and that has been brought into use in the firm.
green_product: TRUE, the article describes retail energy products in states as green products because they are designed, manufactured, and used in a way that significantly reduces their environmental impact throughout their life cycle.
green_process: FALSE, the article does not provide a sufficient description of any processes to determine whether they meet the criteria to be green processes.
likely_naics_codes: ['221112 - Electric Power Generation', '221113 - Electric Power Transmission, Control, and Distribution', '221121 - Fossil Fuel Electric Power Generation', '221122 - Hydroelectric Power Generation']
greenwashing: FALSE, the article does not provide any evidence to suggest that retail energy choice in states is an example of greenwashing.

title: Hart Energy's 2023 ESG Awards: Cleaner, Safer, More Diverse - Hart Energy
summary: The article highlights companies and their efforts to reduce their environmental impact and improve their social and governance practices, with a focus on green innovation and business innovation.  The article includes examples of companies that are implementing green products, green processes, and business innovations, across both the public and private sectors of the energy industry supply chain. Several companies are recognized for their ESG efforts, including Pioneer Natural Resources, Talos Energy, PureWest Energy, Sentinel Peak Resources, Baker Hughes, ChampionX, Danos, Integrity BioChem, Archrock, Crestwood Equity Partners, Aris Water Solutions, and XRI Holdings.

title: Making Renewable, Infinitely Recyclable Plastics Using Bacteria – Berkeley Lab News Center - Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (.gov)
summary: Researchers engineered E. coli to turn sugar from plants into the raw materials for biorenewable plastics called PDKs, that can be efficiently recycled over and over again. Replacing petrochemicals with the bio alternative expanded the PDK’s working temperature, opening applications in the auto industry and beyond. With even modest improvements, using bio alternatives could be both greener and cheaper than petrochemicals in the near-term.
green_innovation: TRUE, the innovation described is a new type of plastic that can be infinitely recycled and is made from biorenewable materials.
business_innovation: TRUE, the innovation described is a new type of plastic that can be infinitely recycled and is made from biorenewable materials, which could be both greener and cheaper than traditional plastics.
green_product: TRUE, the innovation described is a new type of plastic that can be infinitely recycled and is made from biorenewable materials.
green_process: FALSE, the article does not describe a green process.

title: Inside the 'supermarket of the future' promising to waste less energy and less food - FoodNavigator.com
summary: 1) Danfoss has opened a 1,500 sqm flagship store in Nordborg, Denmark, that runs off sustainable energy sources and reuses excess heat to cut heating costs by up to 90%.  2) The store is expected to be around 50% more energy efficient compared to a typical supermarket and will serve as a development center for testing new technology.  3) Danfoss hopes the store will inspire food retailers to move towards zero emissions supermarkets.
green_innovation: TRUE - The store is designed to be energy efficient and sustainable, using renewable energy sources, heat recovery, and other green technologies.
business_innovation: TRUE - The store is a new and improved business process for supermarkets, offering energy efficiency solutions and a development center for testing new technology.
green_product: TRUE - The store uses energy-efficient products, such as LED lighting and refrigeration systems that use natural refrigerants.
green_process: TRUE - The store uses green processes, such as heat recovery and solar power, to reduce its environmental impact.

title: New system design for PVT systems coupled with air-to-water reversible heat pump - pv magazine International
summary: A new design for energy systems based on photovoltaic-thermal (PVT) panels integrated with an air-to-water heat pump via thermal storage tanks has been proposed by researchers at the University of Zaragoza in Spain. The system is intended to provide space heating, cooling, domestic hot water (DHW), and electricity to industrial buildings. The scientists tested the proposed system design over a 5-month period in a real system deployed at an industrial facility owned by Spanish PVT specialist Endef in Zaragoza.

green_product: TRUE. The proposed system is a green product because it is a good or service that is designed, manufactured, and used in a way that significantly reduces its environmental impact throughout its life cycle.
green_process: TRUE. The proposed system is a green process because it is a method or technique in manufacturing, production, or any other operational activity that minimizes environmental impacts and promotes sustainability.

title: Breweries' leftovers brew up a storm: transforming waste into wealth - Innovation Origins
summary: Brewery waste, once considered a disposal problem, is now recognized as a valuable resource. Innovative approaches are transforming this waste into nutritious food, biofuel, bioplastics, and other valuable products, contributing to a circular economy and reducing environmental impact.

title: Direct lithium extraction: The companies at play (part 2/2) - ShareCafe
summary: 1. Direct lithium extraction (DLE) is a technology used to extract lithium from brine without evaporation ponds, reducing environmental impact and water usage. 2. Several companies, including Lilac Solutions, EnergyX, and Sunresin New Materials, are developing and using DLE technologies to produce lithium in a more sustainable way. 3. DLE has the potential to alleviate a lithium supply crisis and contribute to the growing demand for lithium-ion batteries.
green_innovation: TRUE, DLE reduces environmental impact and water usage in lithium extraction.
business_innovation: TRUE, DLE is a new and improved process for extracting lithium that differs significantly from traditional methods.
green_product: TRUE, DLE produces a high-purity lithium product without the environmental impacts of traditional lithium mining.
green_process: TRUE, DLE uses less water and energy, and produces less waste, than traditional lithium mining processes.

title: Niger Delta Exploration & Production PLC to unveil new brand identity - TheCable
summary: NDEP, a fully integrated energy group in Nigeria, plans to unveil a new brand identity on August 4, 2023. The company aims to better reflect its current and future portfolio, and its long-term strategy to become the leading African company delivering sustainable energy solutions that support economic growth. NDEP will continue to focus on the production and distribution of gas, which it sees as a pathway to net zero.

title: Exclusive: Anand Group opens new tech centre in Gurugram under Anevolve-Headspring JV - Autocar Professional
summary: Anand Group has established a technology centre in Gurugram, Haryana, India, for developing e-mobility products and technologies such as on-board chargers and BLDC controllers for two-, three- and four-wheeler EV applications. The R&D centre will develop on-board chargers and inverters for electric four-wheelers, chargers for electric two- and three-wheelers, as well as BLDC controllers.   The centre will employ skilled professionals and leverage in-house expertise in hardware, software, mechanics, and supply chain management, and integrate it with sophisticated tools to innovate new products.
